title: Can a CH7 Trustee claim Bona Fide Purchaser when the property was fraudulently transferred into the estate by Quit Claim Deed?
question: I transferred real estate from myself to a LLC, which I am the managing member, by Quit Claim Deed. I then filed CH11 on the LLC. The CH11 was converted to CH7 by the Court. A creditor wants the property transferred back to me and out of the CH7 estate so he can collect money I owe him. The Trustee is claiming Bona Fide Purchaser; the creditor is claiming Fraudulent Transfer within 4 years that California law provides for. I was insolvent when I made the transfer. I need a US Court Case, or California Supreme Court case, on point. I find many cases where property is transferred out of the estate before filing bankruptcy; this matter is a reverse.
question_tags: LLC (limited liability company),Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate documents,Real estate buy and sell agreements,Real estate quitclaim deed,Property title,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate
answers: You should work closely with your bankruptcy lawyer. If you file the bankruptcy on your own under the current case facts, you are playing with fire. Edward C. Ip www.lawyer4property.com

This is a bit of strange position. You may be one of the first people I have meet hoping for a fraudulent transfer ruling.

With that being said, in order to be a BFP, you must meet the definition of a BFP.

In Black's 9th, which may be slightly different than the controlling definition in your district, you must buy something for value without notice of another's claim to the property and without actual or constructive notice of any defects in or infirmities, claims, or equities against the seller's title - in order to be a BFP.

I am sure there is case law where a Trustee is determine to be or not to be a BFP.

You have potential for a number of bad things coming out of this case like bad faith filing which you may be personally liable for certain costs and damages.

The big question here is whether this creditor is secured. If the creditor is secured against the property, then he just has to follow the procedures to get the property back.

I am not clear enough on your goals to understand your problem.

As the other attorney said, the strong arm powers of a trustee are serious.

Good luck.

Unless the trustee had notice of your fraudulent transfer, IMO the trustee's avoiding powers as a BFP under the strong arm clause allows the trustee to prevail over the claim of the creditor. You should review cases citing 11 U.S.C. section 544(a).
